normalised: **Veggie Ventures: My Hilarious (and Inaccurate) Grocery Games**
Right, let us talk about grocery shopping. It is a battlefield. A colourful, fragrant, sometimes slightly bruised battlefield. And the weapon of choice? A rusty understanding of units of measurement.

unnormalised: **Veggie Ventures: My Hilarious (and Inaccurate) Grocery Games**
normalised: I mean, who actually knows what "a bunch" of coriander is? My mom would confidently grab enough to feed a small village, whereas I usually end up with approximately three sprigs, barely enough to garnish my dal. She also is never happy with my purchase of "half kilogram" of onions because apparently her "half kilogram" is roughly equivalent to seven onions... or is it eight? Oh God.

unnormalised: Right, let’s talk about grocery shopping. It's a battlefield. A colourful, fragrant, sometimes slightly bruised battlefield. And the weapon of choice? A rusty understanding of units of measurement.
normalised: It all started innocently enough. A simple trip to the sabzi mandi. My mission: acquire "two hundred and fifty grams" of paneer. Easy, right? Wrong. The shopkeeper gives me that classic Indian head-bob (which, let us be honest, could mean anything from "yes" to "aliens are real"). He throws a vaguely cube-shaped lump on the scale. It reads "two hundred and seventy five grams". "Chalega?" he asks, with a twinkle in his eye. Of course, it "chalega". I am not about to argue over twenty five grams of paneer when I am already sweating in the Delhi heat. It is better to deal with the extra "twenty five grams" than to argue over a few rupees.

normalised: Then came the Great Potato Predicament. I needed potatoes. "One kilogram aloo, bhaiyya," I declare, confidently. He dumps what looks like a landslide of potatoes into a bag. I eyeball it. Looks like... maybe one point five kilograms? My internal monologue spirals. "Do I say something? Am I turning into one of *those* customers?" Nah. The fear of confrontation wins. Now I have enough potatoes to start my own chips factory. I could have also just asked for “ten potatoes," but where is the fun in that?

normalised: And do not even get me started on the “dalia” (cracked wheat). My grandma’s recipe calls for “one cup.” Now, is that a standard measuring cup? A tea cup? One of those giant, decorative mugs you get as a Diwali gift and never use? I opted for the giant mug. My dalia turned out looking like a giant, beige mountain. The dog enjoyed it, though. He thinks I am slowly trying to convert him into a weightlifter, one enormous bowl of carbs at a time.

normalised: The thing is, I am pretty sure the sabziwalas are in on it. They operate on some sort of… intuition-based measurement system. "Thoda aur?" they will ask, adding a handful of chillies that could set your tongue on fire. “Bas, bhaiyya, bas!” I plead, imagining my intestines staging a rebellion. I also think they adjust their scales based on your perceived wealth. If you look like you are rolling in dough, that "five hundred grams" of tomatoes suddenly weighs a whole lot more.

normalised: And then, of course, there is the inherent chaos of a crowded market. You are dodging auto-rickshaws, negotiating with vendors, and trying to remember if you already bought methi (fenugreek). Amidst all this madness, accurate measurements are, shall we say, a low priority. I saw one person buying "one hundred grams" of something, then another asking for "Ek paav." It is like a historical tour through weights and measures, if you stop to think about it.
